concept.title: Use case scenario: Analyzing customer paths that led to a purchase
concept.shortdesc: A customer data analyst can use Journey Analytics to examine customer paths that led to the purchase of a product. These insights can be shared with customer experience designers, who can use them to design new customer experiences for future product launches.

conbody.p: Last year, CityCool, a developer of consumer technology, unveiled a new electronic watch called SleekFit. After a profitable market response and positive feedback from consumers, CityCool is ready to launch Sleekﬁt 2.0. Anthony, CityCool's customer experience analyst, wants to support the Sleekﬁt 2.0 launch to help their emerging wearable products division meet their business goal of increasing revenue by 10%.

Anthony logs in to and enters criteria to focus his analysis. He uses the path analysis features of to limit his analysis to the Top-Tier Buyers segment. He specifies that he wants to see only the top five paths, ranked by the most traveled.

Next, Anthony defines an end anchor touch point to limit the results only to paths that ended in a cart purchase of the Sleekfit 1.0 product. He sets the look-back range to seven days to see all of the interactions that occurred during the seven days that led up to the purchase. Then, he runs the report.

The results show the top five most-traveled paths that led to a purchase of Sleekfit 1.0, and the channels that customers used along the path. Anthony views a more detailed time-lapse analysis of a path. Although the average time elapsed between the promotional email and the cart purchase touch points was seven days, most Top Tier Buyers bought a Sleekfit 1.0 within two days of receiving an email with a Free Shipping offer. Anthony saves the path analysis and uses the Collaboration feature to share what he has learned with CityCool’s user experience design team. He can then use Journey Designer to recommend a storyboard template as the foundation for new customer experience designs.
